relationÔÉÅ

DefinitionÔÉÅ

A relation is a set of ordered pairs [1]. Equivalently, it is a property of sets such that, for any two members of sets \(a\) and \(b\), \(aRb\) is either true or false [2].

Syntactically, a relation is represented with a

A relation ‚óÜ is a theoretical-object for formula. It assigns the following meaning to its composite formula ùúë: ùúë establishes a relation between its parameters. A relation ‚óÜ has a fixed arity.

Key propertiesÔÉÅ

  • arity

  • notation-form

  • signal-proposition (TODO: rename to propositional)

  • symbolic-representation

Punctilious data modelÔÉÅ

Python implementationÔÉÅ

In punctilious, relations are implemented by the core.Relation class.

A catalog of well-known relations is handily available in the RelationDict‚Ä¶

RelationÔÉÅ

class core.Relation(universe_of_discourse, arity, symbol=None, index=None, auto_index=None, formula_rep=None, signal_proposition=None, signal_theoretical_morphism=None, implementation=None, dashed_name=None, acronym=None, abridged_name=None, name=None, explicit_name=None, ref=None, subtitle=None, nameset=None, echo=None)ÔÉÅ

The Relation pythonic class is the implementation of the relation theoretical-object.
